topic: Write a 500-word essay about climate change and what your generation can do.
essay_text:
Climate change. Just hearing those words can make you feel a whole spectrum of things  dread, anxiety, even outright denial. Honestly, I get it. It's overwhelming. We're bombarded with images of melting glaciers and apocalyptic weather events, paired with dense scientific reports that feel impossible to decipher. It feels like this massive problem has been foisted upon us, a pre-packaged ecological disaster box left on our generational doorstep. But the truth is, dwelling in despair or resignation is playing directly into the hands of inaction. My generation, Gen Z, inherited this challenge, yes, but we also inherited the tools, the technology, and most importantly, the audacity to do something about it.

We're Digital Natives. This isn't just a bragging right; it's a superpower. Information is at our fingertips. We consume news and dissect it with a level of skepticism rare in previous generations. We understand how social media can be used to amplify messages, mobilize action, and shame those who are obstructing progress. TikTok might seem like just a platform for dances and dog pictures, but it's also become a powerful tool for social activism, allowing young people to educate each other, connect with professionals, and bypass traditional media gatekeepers to share information about climate solutions. We're organizing online, creating movements, and engaging in discussions happening offline too, in our communities and schools.

Our activism isn't limited to the digital realm. Look at the youth climate strikes. Led by figures like Greta Thunberg, they demonstrated sheer force of organization and an unwavering commitment to holding adults accountable. We're participating in local elections, supporting eco-conscious businesses, and advocating for sustainable policies within our own communities. We're understanding that climate solutions come in many forms, not just top-down legislation. Buying less, walking or cycling more, and advocating for plant-based alternatives at family dinners might seem insignificant, but collectively, these conscious choices ripple outwards.

But lets be real, individual responsibility goes only so far. Genuine change hinges on systemic solutions. Thats where we need to leverage our political clout. Holding our elected officials accountable, donating to environmental organizations, and becoming involved in advocacy groups are not optional civic duties, they are vital. This means staying informed and active  understanding the nuances of climate legislation, engaging in civil discourse (even  and especially  with those who disagree with us), and persistently demanding that sustainability considerations be prioritized. We have to move the argument from whether or not we should address climate change to *how* we address it.

Finally, and perhaps most importantly, we need to challenge the systems that have historically contributed to this crisis. This means critiquing consumer culture, pushing for equitable environmental policies that protect vulnerable communities, and demanding corporate accountability for unsustainable practices. We Gen Z arent naive about capitalism or its effect on the world around this system.

We are walking towards an uncertain future, no question. But our ability to recognize the problems facing the Earth while still actively taking part in solutions grants a hope for future generations. Denying we could stop them? Not an option. Making change wherever and however the opportunity lies? Now *that's* something. The crisis around the conversation of Earth climate continues... we have a fight on our hands. Luckily enough, it isnt a fight on out hearts. Fight and survive by all necessary means of our power.

Were the inheritors of this increasingly urgent predicament, and accepting our defeat before the fight even begins is something future generations won't forgive.

And because.We should stop using digital communications or online movements. Not as simply places, but instead is powerful opportunities. From there actions becomes viral with people can organize, engage, & disseminate awareness quickly. I honestly don't believe older generations used the internet and for organizing effectively such us. Then our generation can transform passive recognition & online activism of the problem towards practical implementation easily! 
But real action is about action as much it is communication . While reducing disposable consumption, for example is common sense, it starts a conversation around rethinking what necessities actually are? What the value consumer items means to each other? We just needed make sure we adopt behaviors from all areas that directly benefit environments while at the same time encouraging many others on doing those same activities! Then change becomes unstoppable
In the absence of perfect solutions right now, but it is our role is figure better ways implementing everyday solutions towards fighting!
The reality is, climate change is scary. The scale of the action needed can feel daunting. topic: Write a 500-word essay about climate change and what your generation can do.
essay_text:
Climate change. It's the background hum of anxiety you hear every time you flip on the news. Another weather record broken, another glacier melting, another scientist practically screaming into the void about irreversible damage. Honestly, its easy to feel overwhelmed and helpless about something that seems so massive and complex. We're inheriting a problem decades in the making, a mess largely created by generations before ours. So, what can my generation, the blurry-lined Millennials and Gen Z, realistically do?

First thing everyone always brings up: individual actions. Reducing plastic consumption, recycling, eating less meat, taking public transport. And sure, that all matters. Of course it does. But let's be real, convincing all your flatmates to ditch their plastic cutlery isnt going to suddenly reverse global warming. Individual actions become potent when adopted en masse, turning individual choices into a collective current strong enough to drive meaningful change. It's about showing that sustainable choices are not just niche hobbies for the intensely virtuous, they are becoming the norm.

More importantly, action means getting political. Climate change isnt something that your reusable KeepCup can solve. It's systemically baked into industries and regulatory systems the world over. Meaningful action requires a paradigm shift implemented at scale by governments and corporations. Voting strategically, supporting candidates who prioritize climate agendas and holding local representatives accountablethese are the levers that can genuinely effect change. We need to demand ambitious climate policies from our leaders and then ensure they get implemented.

Beyond political pressures, investing in a green future is vital. That means actively researching companies investment portfolios to make sure it reflects a desire to be carbon neutral or negatively impactful to improve global climates, buying stocks in renewable resources as options for the future, funding young creators, and helping spread the word about organizations whose funding directly impacts conservation work, whether marine or wild lives.

My generation, especially Gen Z, are digitally connected and socially conscious in a way that earlier generations simply werent. We need to harness the power of online networks to amplify vital voices, share accurate information, and debunk misinformation. Social platforms amplify these effects, but we have to become more thoughtful content moderators because people will find information, be informed, changed, then move on. essay_text:
## The Burden and the Bridge: Navigating Climate Change, One Generation at a Time

Lets be real. Talking about climate change feels like holding a gargantuan problem in your already-full hands. We, the younger generation, inherited a planet teetering from decades of unchecked consumption and disregarded warnings. It's a sobering reality, and sometimes, terrifyingly overwhelming. But heres the thing: burying our heads in the sand isnt an option. This isn't a problem for future generations to solve; it demands our immediate engagement.

Were often told we're responsible for fixing the mess. And yeah, to some degree, it's true. Were facing rising sea levels hitting vulnerable coastlines, extreme weather patterns becoming the norm, and the devastating loss of biodiversity that defines our natural world. No pressure, right? But I think this fix it mentality, while stemming from good intentions, can be paralyzing. It places an impossibly heavy yoke on our shoulders. I argue it's not about miraculously undoing the damage. Its about building a bridge to a more sustainable future.

So, how do we build that bridge? Firstly, **information is our bedrock**. We are the generation raised with Google at our fingertips. We need to actively seek out credible information about climate science, political policy, and sustainable practices. Understand the nuances. Challenge misinformation. Engage in informed and respectful dialogue. Knowing the facts empowers us to advocate effectively and make choices that are genuinely impactful. Knowing the impact of our actions, even minute ones, is paramount.

Beyond knowledge, **our economic power is a force we can wield.** We decide what we buy, where we work, and who we support with our choices. Consciously choosing products and services from companies committed to sustainability sends a powerful message demanding that businesses embrace ethical practices. We can favor local, sustainable food systems over mass-produced options. We can support companies dedicated to reducing their carbon footprint. Opting out of fast fashion, embracing circular economies, and advocating for renewable energy options - these choices, collectively enacted, create significant market pressure for climate-conscious innovation.

However, individual choices alone arent enough. We desperately need **systemic change**, and this is where our collective voice becomes paramount. Voting in elections aligned with environmental protection policies is non-negotiable. Boycotting detrimental corporations is impactful. Actively participating in grassroots movements and advocacy groups, even if its just signing a petition or attending a local meeting, amplifies our call for change. Weve seen the power of youth activism - Greta Thunbergs impact, the energy in Fridays for Future - it proves our voices can, and should, be heard. We need to push our elected officials  locally and nationally  to enact policies that incentivize green innovation, promote renewable energy, and phase out fossil fuel dependency.

Finally, and perhaps most importantly, we need to **foster a society built on empathy and understanding**. Climate change disproportionately affects marginalized communities, exacerbating existing inequalities. Our bridge cannot be a bridge solely built for the privileged. We need to ensure equitable access to clean energy, resilient infrastructure, and sustainable food systems for everyone, everywhere. This means understanding the intersectionality of climate change and social justice. Learning about the lived experiences of vulnerable communities most at risk is absolutely essential.

This challenge is deeply personal. It demands a nuanced approach, not blindly adopting fleeting lifestyles. This isnt about sacrificing pleasure and becoming joyless eco-warriors. This should be about embracing mindful consumption, connecting with community, supporting nature and its creatures and finding purpose through promoting long-term sustainable values into all decision-making in our lives. It feels heavy, I still know: but taking ownership will allow each of us a piece of the bridge from the old to this reimagined reality. If each individual begins, the task is manageable. Climate responsibility for our generation? Responsibility transformed into empowerment.

topic: Write a 500-word essay about whether standardized testing is fair.
essay_text:
## The Tyranny, Trend, and (Tiny) Truth of Standardized Tests

Ah, standardized tests. Just the phrase itself is enough to induce a cold sweat in students and a furrowed brow in many educators. We spend hours preparing for them, dissecting sample questions, and coaching test-taking strategies, all for a score thats meant to capture some ineffable understanding of a subject area. But is that score, that single number, truly fair? I think anyone whos actually been *through* the system knows the answer is nuanced, complicated, and mostly leans toward a resounding *no*.

One of the biggest arguments against standardized testing is the glaring lack of equity. Consider the student from a low-income background attending an under-resourced school. They simply dont have the same access to advanced tutoring, enriching after-school programs, and stimulating classroom environments as their more affluent peers. The playing field isn't remotely level. Standardized tests, in this context, often become markers of privilege, not necessarily of intrinsic ability or acquired knowledge. A well-meaning student trapped in a challenging system is inevitably punished for circumstances beyond their control, creating a cycle of limited opportunities.

Furthermore, standardized tests often reinforce a narrow definition of "intelligence." They prioritize specific skills, like analytical reasoning and memorization, which might not encompass the full range of valuable talents a student possesses. Many brilliant individuals are simply bad test-takers. They might be remarkably creative artists, empathetic leaders, mechanically gifted tinkerers - skills that arent neatly quantified on a sheet of multiple-choice bubbles. Discounting these multifaceted abilities with a single test score is a disservice to both the individual and the broader goal of education. We lose out on a generation of potentially exceptional individuals by focusing almost obsessively on how well they fill in circles.

Beyond the inherent bias and limited scope, there's also the sheer impact these tests have on curriculum. Lets be honest, we *teach to the test.* Teachers, understandably pressured to boost scores, often prioritize test-related skills and content over broader, more creative learning experiences. This narrows the curriculum, stifles curiosity, and turns schools into test-prep academies, sucking the genuine joy of learning out of the classroom. The consequence? Students become experts at standardized testing but may lack the fundamental capacity for critical thinking and innovative problem-solving, skills ultimately far more valuable in the real world.

That said, arguing against standardization altogether is throwing the baby out with the bathwater. In some contexts, standardized tests can offer a *relatively* objective measure of student performance and educational program effectiveness. They provide a common benchmark, albeit flawed, preventing us from wholly relying on highly subjective and potentially biased teacher evaluations. They also play a crucial (albeit flawed and often stressful) role in college admissions and scholarship eligibility.

So, are standardized tests fair? Largely, no. The existing system perpetuates inequality, inhibits holistic learning, and reduces students to dehumanizing data points. Ultimately, true fairness would mean dismantling many of the inequalities outside, and often exacerbated by, the testing arena itself. However, dismantling the entire concept seems too radical, throwing the useful baby out with the less-than-ideal water. Better regulation, less restrictive teaching, lower dependency, and, perhaps ironically, even more thorough preparation seem like the best, if not ideal, answer to creating somewhat-more fair scenarios. Until a truly equitable educational landscape exists, maybe "somewhat" is the best we can do, sadly.

topic: Write a 500-word essay about whether standardized testing is fair.
essay_text:
The air in the testing hall thickened. A muted cough here, a nervous pen click thereall under the oppressive hush decreed by the ubiquitous "No Talking" signs plastered across the walls. Row upon row of silently working students, unified by a singular goal: conquering the standardized test that loomed before them as a gatekeeper to their futures. But is that gatekeeper a fair judge, a true measure of skill and potential, or merely a standardized reflection distorted by the systemic inequalities prevalent in our society? The question of whether standardized testing is truly fair is, unsurprisingly, less a sharp demarcation and more a sprawling landscape of grey.

On one hand, proponents will argue about its objective nature, its supposed equal playing field. At least, on the surface. Everyone receives the same questions, follows the same timed format, and is graded according to the same predetermined rubric. In theory, this mitigates the potential for bias a la classroom grades that inadvertently award students on subjective factors like class participation styles or unconscious teacher favoritism. It offers a quantifiable, comparable metric to assess aptitude and potential for success. High schools can sort students into accelerated courses; colleges can sift through thousands of applications. Standardized tests, in this light, are simply efficient.

Yet, that initial sheen of objectivity quickly dulls upon deeper reflection. The notion of an "equal playing field" immediately faces the challenge of unequal access to resources. Test-taking skills, while undoubtedly honed through hours of study and practice, are disproportionately accessible to students from affluent backgrounds. Expensive test prep courses, individualized tutoring, and enriching extracurricular activities that build critical thinking and vocabulary: these advantages are not available equitably to all. To suggest a child coming from a underfunded school, juggling responsibilities with after-school jobs, faces an equal standing at the SAT with a student coached intensively for months with access to hundreds of practice exams is simply disingenuous. Standardized tests thus become not true indicators of innate potential, but rather accurate readings of socioeconomic privilege.

Furthermore, standardized tests often prioritize certain types of learning and problem-solving skills valued in academic settings but only marginally valuable in real-world scenarios. Rote memorization and quick processing take center stage over critical thinking, creativity, and alternative problem-solving stylesskills equally valuable, if not more, outside the structured confines of a traditional classroom. We risk valuing and validating students who are good at "playing the game" rather than those with genuinely innovative minds whose talents may not find a place to shine within rigid test parameters.

Ultimately, blaming standardized tests is not as simple as dismissing them outright. No assessment tool is perfect, and other methods often come with their own inherent biases and pitfalls. Alternatives such as portfolio development and competency-based testing, which allows students to demonstrate skills through various means, have potential, but also present challenges in terms of standardization and resource allocation. The pursuit of equitable assessment should thus rely not on the abolition of any single method of grading, but rather a concerted commitment to ensuring equal access, diverse evaluation, and a critical understanding that standardized tests, when and where they're used, are just one facet - and not the defining character - of a complex, growing person's overall worth and potential. The goal is not necessarily to level the playing fielda fundamentally impossible task in an unequal societybut to use all tools, tests or otherwise, to paint honest, multifaceted images of everyone's future to create as honest possibilities that their humanity deserves.

essay_text:
## The Number Game: Why Standardized Testing's "Fairness" is Up for Debate

Standardized tests. For years, theyve loomed large in education, gatekeepers to universities, passports to careers. Were told theyre fair, a standardized yardstick to measure everyone by. But peel back the promise and you'll find a tangle of perspectives and a deeply troubling reality  that what we consider "fair" in this context is often subjective, flawed, and ultimately, leaves many students behind.

On the surface, the logic is neat and tidy. A standardized test offers equal footing: every student answers the same questions under the same timed conditions, leveled and compared purely on demonstrated knowledge. This, proponents argue, minimizes prejudice and bias, providing an objective way to assess ability divorced from subjective grading schemes and potential teacher biases. This is, indeed, an attractive picture; a supposed playing field that levels everything.

However, the truth is that this playing field is far from even. Background advantages, like affluent schools and access to tutoring, give certain students a tremendous head start. These are resources that translate directly into test scores. Students from poorer communities, who may face overcrowded classrooms, lack of resources, and the pressures of familial responsibilities, immediately start at a disadvantage. The same test, therefore, serves as a stark reminder of socio-economic disparities, solidifying, rather than bridging, the education gap.

Furthermore, standardized tests, by their nature, prioritize specific types of intelligence. High reliance is placed on recall and rapid problem-solving within rigid time constraints. This approach overlooks creativity, critical thinking, and the deep understanding gained through hands-on experience. Consequently, exceptionally capable students who thrive in creative or project-based learning environments might find themselves underestimated and unfairly categorized based on their standardized test performance. The implication that their inherent intelligence resides beneath acceptable averages.

There's a deeper problem too: the tests are largely reliant on the types questions of test-makers and consultants who frequently do not resemble the makeup of diversity within the broader population that utilizes these standardized tests frequently. Language and cultural nuances that seem negligible have an unfair impact on minorites who, on the broader perspective, bring unique perspective into American classroom

The argument often surfaces defending against this stance is that these unfairnesses exist *outside* of the fairness model that standard testing seeks implement, and not through intention but, in it's consequence, through the unfairness the the system generates without actually, literally and, "Fairly" affecting any different race, background or class. Many are convinced here and see that a blind equality and not justice, may be better at producing these systems even when at cost. 

Ultimately, while standardized testing may strive for objectivity, its inherent limitations and exacerbation of existing inequalities make its purported "fairness" questionable at best. True educational equity demands a multifaceted approach that acknowledges individual strengths, encourages diverse forms of assessment, and addresses the systemic disparities that deny students a fair and equal opportunity from the very start. When this day ever comes, we may see an actually functioning, properly and fair implementation that better balances the needs across the human board of capabilities within and out the box. For now, though, the number game remains far from a level ground.

essay_text:
## The Standardized Soul: In Search of Fairness in Education

Standardized testing. The phrase alone can send shivers down the spines of students, parents, and even some teachers. These tests wield immense power, shaping academic trajectories and acting as gatekeepers to opportunities and resources. The crux of the issue, though, is this: are they fair? Is a single, narrowly focused snapshot of knowledge truly indicative of potential and ability? Or are they inherently, and perhaps irrevocably, tilted against certain populations, widening the already existing achievement gaps?

On the one hand, the supposed appeal of standardized tests lies in their objectivity. In theory, everyone takes the same test, under the same conditions, answering the same questions. Sounds fair enough, right? Proponents argue they provide a consistent metric, allowing for comparisons across schools, districts, and even states, holding institutions accountable. They offer a seemingly neutral way to assess curriculum efficacy and, in fields like medicine and law, filter out potentially unfit candidates. Imagine, the argument goes, leaving important decisions to purely subjective evaluation - chaos would reign!

However, the reality is far more complex. "The Man" who is standardized tests overlooks a crucial element: humans aren't machines. They don't arrive at the testing table as blank slates. Instead, they come laden with a vast array of experiences, resources, and cultural baggage, all of which inevitably impact their performance. 

Think about socio-economic backgrounds. Students from wealthier families often have access to better schooling, tutoring programs, and the subtle cues ingrained in them about succeeding within the education system. They are better equipped to navigate the standardized dance and decipher the unwritten rules of answering questions in correct ways. Conversely, students from underprivileged backgrounds may face systemic disadvantages that significantly impact their ability to excel on these tests. Issues such as lack of access to resources, poor nutrition, or the added burden of family responsibilities can all contribute to a student underperforming, regardless of their inherent intelligence and motivation.

Furthermore, the very content of standardized tests can reflect a cultural bias. Tests, generally created and normed by individuals predominantly from one socio-economic and cultural background, may favour concepts and examples that resonate more strongly within that subgroup. Questions that assume a certain level of cultural literacy can be inadvertently exclusionary, placing non-native English speakers and those unfamiliar with specific cultural landscapes at a significant disadvantage. This isn't intentional, necessarily, but this can also unintentionally perpetuate biases.

Looking at accessibility reveals another level complex issue with equity. Standardized test may favor only people with standard mental capacity and ability to take said test thus, potentially blocking some people who may or who would want to proceed and progress toward their studies and education. 

The argument for fairness in standardized testing boils down to this: while the intention may be noble, its current reality is anything but consistently fair. To truly assess a student's potential, we must move beyond the limitations of isolated tests and embrace a more holistic approach. This includes incorporating teacher assessments, project-based learning, portfolios, and creative problem-solving opportunities. Only then can we design an educational system that celebrates the unique talents of each individual, giving everyone a fair shot instead of enforcing narrow, limited standards. Standardizations cannot achieve that type of freedom.

topic: Write a 500-word essay about whether standardized testing is fair.
essay_text:
The stack of answer sheets seems to stretch to infinity, a silent testament to years of frantic studying and stressed-out test-takers. Standardized testing. That phrase alone can trigger anxiety in students and fiery debates among educators. And it all boils down to one big question: is it fair? 

Honestly, there's no easy yes or no answer. On the one hand, standardized tests are pitched as a level playing field. Every student gets the same questions, the same timeframe, and their scores are supposed to give a uniform measure of their knowledge. Ideally, this translates into an objective way to compare schools, measure student growth, and make responsible college admissions decisions or scholarship offers. Think about it: universities wading through thousands of applicants need *some* metric to narrow the field. It sounds simple enough, theoretically.

But that's where the "ideal" part breaks down quickly when compared to reality. The reality is, fair assumes everyone starts at the same place. And nobody does. The simple truth is that kids from wealthy backgrounds benefit immensely from the system. Theyre more likely to have access to tutoring, attend well-funded schools with smaller class sizes and more qualified teachers, and even have the implicit confidence that comes from growing up knowing you have advantages others dont. Taking practice tests and reviewing material at home with a personal tutor isn't exactly cheap, but those extra points earned can significantly impact test results, pushing certain students into higher percentile brackets. Poverty becomes a barrier, not just to educationally relevant things like textbooks, but also to test-taking support.

Furthermore, these tests were often written decades ago and may simply have subtle cultural biases embedded in their questions and wording impacting marginalized populations. Asking me whether or not I could pick out the obscure classical guitarist is like speaking a second language. Some researchers believe that the test environments themselves favor the children who aren't distracted but their worries about food insufficiency may be getting passed on. The idea is that test companies like the Collegeboard, and the organizations running school corporations never really did account for variables impacting testing results until lately and they really did not get the memo.

Beyond socioeconomic factors, consider students with learning differences or disabilities. They might be bright, curious, and bursting with potential, but standardized exams frequently fail to account for those attributes. While accommodations like extended time exist, they don't always level the playing field. The format, the stress involved, the rote memorization so often rewarded - those things simply disadvantage good kids who learn a little bit differently, yet have plenty of useful information.

Whats needed is context: Can standardized tests point useful metrics when educators fully study students and measure growth taking into account who they are and what experiences have prepared children. As a measurement instrument, a standardized math tests for elementary school boys is not enough in its single purpose - it must be backed -up with information that reflects the whole child.

So, are standardized tests fair? It's complex. They strive for objectivity but often fail to overcome deep-seated inequalities and learning variations. They can offer some benefit when providing indicators of potential performance if carefully reviewed. Standardized tests are a tool they have benefits for sure - we just can't pretend they're the *final* word or the perfect reflection test of capability and skill.

Social media is everywhere. A constant hum. It is woven into the fabric of modern life. This constant connectivity can impact young minds, especially teens still developing.

For many teens, social media provides a powerful link to their peers. A way to navigate feelings that have risen with the surge of hormones. It's there to reach out. Support and connection. Friendships blossom online even in the weirdest corners which can really help the teen feel loved. Online identity for some teens has morphed into complete reality or sometimes, even a better personality than real life where their anxieties run rampant. Yay, now they are not alone! However it does bring some downfalls as all humans can attest to there are some dangerous characters hiding behind a happy photo and enticing description.

However, heres where things get murkier. The positive effects of building friendships and feeling like someone is there for them. Now how about the comparisons. It all leads to that, doesn't it? Think back to school cafeterias except you cannot mute it!

The very makeup of platforms like Instagram, TikTok, and even X (bleh) facilitates unending cycles of social comparison. Teens are constantly bombarded. Polished highlight reels. Images of perfect lives: vacations, flawless bodies, overflowing popularity. This curated reality can lead to feelings of inadequacy, low self-esteem, and body image issues. Especially prevalent for teens who already battle anxiety or depressive patterns. Or hell you already have one imperfection a person doesn't like like having acne or stretch marks after doing sports? Bam.

Social media's reward system further complicates the scene. Validation in the form of likes, comments, and followers becomes addictive like caffeine from a coffee beverage on our commute. These interactions provide little boosts dopemine for our teens. Approval turns something they must attain than get, thus forming how their mood gets based upon their internet approval rates.
 This cycle perpetuates users online just so many people can say yay that outfit is super great, I sure would never be brave like you when if they just wanted you! It is a wild feeling it makes me think what about when real life when we feel validation on real interaction. Real connections over a lunch. I will need research that point someday. Cyberbullying creates additional anxieties where they can spread horrible rumors faster than lighting.
 So, the benefits go... so what can we do? Maybe some sort of mindful scrolling that makes it easier to keep sane?

Social media, as we have learned provides a paradox with so amazing results where we have groups that have helped in cancer recoveries of teens and adults, and it also gives more of a burden for many if taken the right route.

topic: Write a 500-word essay about a book that changed your perspective.
essay_text:
Okay, challenge accepted. Here goes nothing

Books, they just sit there. Silent. Until they aren't.

Then BAM! Your whole darn thinking shifts. Never the same. At least, thats how it felt for me. One hit me HARD.

The book that rearranged my brain was "Sapiens: A Brief History of Humankind" by Yuval Noah Harari. Sounds real pretentious, I know. Like Oh look at me, Im reading a BRITh history of HUMANKIND. Seriously, get over yourself brain. But bear with me, it actually deserves its reputation. It's not about knowing the answers, but making connections. Harari takes such a broad overview, zooming way out, and suddenly all the little pieces of human behavior start lining up in ways I never considered before. What pieces? Just little things, all combined somehow into something bigger. I never studied history. It's hard to grasp all by itself.

Seriously, try explaining where someone's brain is going! It just takes off towards everywhere! So I think what stuck with me the most was how... accidental humanity seems to be. See, I always figured there was inevitability to civilization. Right? Like it might take some zigs and zags, a detour through the Dark Ages, you know, hiccups here and there. But *Sapiens* made a convincing argument that none of this NEEDED to happen. I mean, it outlines humanity going through different revolutions. First, the Cognitive Revolution, that language moment let us think different, dream, argue, and strategize which leads to the Agricultural Revolution which actually made life harder. Then the Scientific. These revolutions shaped our social structure even more and lead up to the point we are currently at, which I cannot spell after a big rant haha. Like there was never any kind of guarantee we'd move out to take over. It was all contingent on luckadvantage combined with the *faintest trace to survive*. At *that specific moment in time*. Even luck. So now where are we heading? I cannot even grasp with concepts like climate or societal destruction; a whole mess of random changes from the big bang (or who ever thought about how God would create the big bang in his own image!) What even is real anyway? What IS real, what a huge load. This just blew my mind! What actually happened to my understanding of a straight and natural progression... Oh, god... wait! My whole darn path?! Right, so what about the future? Or even where we had to head to be reading all those history novels? Even thinking or contemplating future-ness? Wait...

Overall thing I think I'm learning is realizing the randomness that exists *around there* is something to work with and be OK seeing that. I dont know... Does any of that make sense? And I would recommend everyone here study a little bit. I want to do that...

topic: Write a 500-word essay about a book that changed your perspective.
essay_text:
Okay, here's a shot at that essay. Sorry if it gets a little messy.

***

Siddhartha by Hermann Hesse. Simple title. Profound impact. Before reading it, I was deeply ensconced in the right way/wrong way mindset. Do well in school. Get a 'good' job. Accumulate stuff. That narrow path wascomfortable.

Then this book happened. A small, literary wrecking ball that messed all kinds of things up.

"Siddhartha" tells the story of, unsurprisingly, Siddhartha. A young man! Set amongst religious life! In the era when *the* Buddha lived, Siddhartha takes on a quest for enlightenment. First of ALL, he throws this away to live amongst common folk in the day by day life. Rejecting the comfort of his privileged upbringing. He's constantly searching, and then, the weirdest thing happens? Never satisfied, Siddhartha does a whole bunch of living to begin finding happiness without enlightenment being his only goal. The teachings of his Brahmin father. The ascetic life as a Samana. A hedonistic experience in a town doing business with common people. All are insufficient! (Like the end to a great sentence in the previous section!) He has to *experience* everything firsthand; and through experience, Siddhartha discovers, there isn't just simply a truth of this or that in our great earth. But instead; a wholeness. I really latched onto a whole concept that can provide balance to just thinking you need material possessions! Or just nothing but great enlightenment. The river! It starts sounding better just talking about this. Now, the river becomes his teacher. But that sounds a bit cheesy because just look at the river just by itself? At it runs and swirls in it's course. Its the water changing form through and in all, from fog to torrential floods, from rains in spring to clear, cold waters of its course throughout an endless year. But really; it demonstrates a beautiful and continuous ebb and flow. An impermanence that reflects... pretty real aspects of life. Like change AND decay? Yeah, Siddhartha sits/learns near constantly watching the neverending changes in the river's qualities. Everything continues as is. Which, I guess... the big picture that started changing in me that this has some big real, practical thing that applies to the daily. My goal shouldn't just focus in all on career pursuits. Or whatever I was doing that was keeping from being the whole meal! As Siddhartha began teaching me.

So, how did this perspective change *me*? Significantly at the time; that is what I see by way of perspective. Definitely, I started questioning everything and that helped develop better ways to be. Maybe a pursuit of the "well-rounded" sounds cliche however by me actually working towards getting better here that allowed the work to sound much less intimidating to complete. Anyway. The book's a gem (a really small, digestible book, so... definitely a plus.)

topic: Write a 500-word essay about a book that changed your perspective.
essay_text:
Okay, let's do this. Give me *Pride and Prejudice*.

***

**Pride, Prejudice, and Perspective: A Shift**

*Pride and Prejudice* and me? An unlikely duo. Frankly: I thought "bonnets" equaled boring. But Austen worked. Miraculously. More on that later.

Austen did more than spin a (admittedly captivating) romance. She challenged things. Power. Class. Womanhood. Very subtly, very cleverly. She made me really *think* About motivations.

Before reading it, history was dry stuff, kings and countries just *doing things*- a very bloodless accounting of things long past. People were characters! This is still true of historical books but I also apply it far wider. Now, I try to understand *reasons* behind actions. Lizzie's independent, sharp-tongued refusal of Mr. Collins? Gold. Sure, it's a societal "faux pas." I realize now that behind every character there's an actual perspective they are acting from, not "men and women". But to refuse a comfortable marriage when your family's prospects are dwindling fast? Even for her time, this was an exercise in self-interest. That's what is interesting really, why didn't all young girls show themselves so willing! We were all stuck under kings and peasants, not one free-willed, free woman willing to speak as needed..

But *why* did she do it, though? Thats the golden part when doing a literary study. Like a good English class that focuses mostly mostly on that. Was it pure stubbornness? Arrogance? Nope! The book deftly unveils it all because she wanted love and she certainly wasnt interested in marrying without it-- especially as with no money or title such as that that Mr. Collins has (and of course that very powerful yet ever gentle Darcy has)

Pride, in all its ghastly glory. Darcysuffocating in snobbery and class concerns yet capable of profound decency, *thats* real conflict! Think hes easy in refusing others- no he has plenty of friends but no true equals nor a woman he knows deep down he is attracted. Seeing both the glaring flaws and the eventual, agonizing growth in these figures made then feel almost real in a way that previous characters I really had thought they were just archetypes, not, I dont, really- thatsw hy I guess the word is character and why the whole goal is character development because if someone is too still it seems so very boring! It wasn't as if everyone even at the age understood it,

So, yes *Pride and Prejudice* kind of broke my world and also made it. Perspective... I am very bad at giving an explanation... It shifted and gave me another perspective and how people are able to explain that I think that sometimes because they just never went into life with such very low expectations like women back then who got married away so very young always should have I do not even like to wonder when I am like because then also things can shift! Just the first person! Now even as I continue with writing there has already been the second personal and the first perspective and the shifts of me doing more because there is time!.

Anyway. To sum: Great understanding. Very enjoyable, makes me wonder, changed things just because that is it makes people great

I used to kinda see that as the job of a history class; turns out, beliefs are way more durable than one assassin and ideas will influence multiple leaders across multiple periods or millennia...Harari breaks down these paradigm shifts. Not paradigm; that's way overwrought of a word! Paradigm Shifts!!! He talks about The Agricultural Revolution not merely as the technological progression like tractors and specialized seeding strategies BUT a monumental shift In how societies structure themselves, in how humans view the world's resources around them, its impact on equality levels too, and on long-term health generally due to reduced variety of food. Harari dissects how we're trapped by this invention, almost stuck to fields. And he links it back to these powerful ideas about territory; control of resources. A system, really, you see repeating over across eras, with subtle evolutions but echoing core principles and strategies all the ways through to the present. Same thing with the cognitive revolution the one where language became way more common  allowing myths  well hes clear it was something like a fiction  at our scale because the size allows for myths about common things to circulate and the bigger your population, the more useful the myths became. Wow getting carried aWAY here...but there a connection...

It made me look at present-day stuff through a different lens, with much wider considerations. Made it clear that even modern things arent necessarily just inventions, they result from something big!

And now? I keep thinking about unintended consequences. And things changing. It's scary; yet hopeful still, to know it is actually happening now if it's always true right and so...?

topic: Write a 500-word essay about a book that changed your perspective.
essay_text:
Okay, here's my attempt at that essay, keeping in mind you wanted a B+ vibe with some meandering and varied sentence structure! Its all coming together, promise!

***

The book that did it for me? Siddhartha by Hermann Hesse. A short jaunt into someone else's journey. Basically about finding enlightenment. You know the gist. Changed my whole understanding of well, everything.

The real kicker? It wasn't some grand, complex argument drawing you in with facts and making promises, but a simple fable wrapped in beautiful prose. It's kinda brilliant, that way. Simple. Accessible. And yet. Deep.

Siddhartha tells the journey a guy simply known as Siddhartha, who leaves his privileged life as a Brahmin's son to seek enlightenment with his friend Govindaa sort of ride away from his normal path in pursuit of ultimate knowing. Sounds great on its face! He bounces around... I realize I don't know which word to say next now.....anygayss... it isn't some straightforward, follow all of the paths you come across, linear way of arriving. He joins the ascetics, trying to find truth in denial of his basic desires to be an acceptable body, I mean not that he has any issues it is mainly what they enforce.... It does and does that, as does their whole lifestyle that is the opposite to this kind. However, there is the "that," that keeps that entire part not that significant at all which makes total sense like the other stuff but makes the argument a little different too. Like, you know that the same concepts do matter on one hand. Then he becomes seduced like everyone becomes when they give up, who cares?! The world becomes even bigger when it encompasses, let's say he turns materialistic. He becomes obsessed (at first)with material gain. Love? Lust perhaps! Power?! In whatever this all might or might not imply, the journey is all what gets that specific stuff done. I started losing my train of thought but its making sense to me or so I think so... he eventually leaves this hedonistic world, disgusted with himself (lol, same, just joking). The cool part is, get this!, it isn't until Siddhartha relinquishes striving, only upon accepting life, as everything that it is on its own where all the crap has come to an end....he kind he will find his version I mean with the real answers lying in the wisdom of experiencing, not in some abstract text or teacher that I realize are the exact words I am doing in trying so far! Okay, not being bad.

So, ultimately, Siddhartha's wandering life really spoke to me because the real wisdom comes not from instruction, because there is literally no one's journey I care enough to take over. It's more useful and even cooler to find your version without feeling like I might forget anything crucial. Finding enlightenment? It has to come through this whole exploration. Its kinda awesome that way because you get the chance to discover the right path with out feeling forced to just be normal person it's been a wild, emotional ride to get here! But. Worth it!. I can do better!.

Okay, wow right, so climate change is huge. A big deal. A real disaster. Our planet, our future. Seriously jeopardized.

For real though, every news cycle is like, a new terrifying climate report. Melting glaciers, rising sea levels  it's the damn *Waterworld* movie coming to life, for Christ's sake! And forest fires everywhere. Basically it's making me feel a bit doomed and hopeless Im not going to even try to hide it. Who can blame us?
What Can My Gen Do?

I mean, the pressure is on *us,* my generation, right? Fixing issues from before anyone my age held any amount power or financial advantages, so whatever, it has fallen to my age and cohort.
While also being in what looks to be 1% territory in being more stressed, more anxiety, and more feeling hopelessness than all prior generations.
Cool. Thank goodness for technology and the ways innovation can address complex issues, right!!! But all these issues all piled on each other means that climate change won't fall because individuals recycle - or go to electric cars while the economy still hinges on oil industries . As much as 'reduce, reuse, recycle' got branded into our skulls at elementary school assembly: systemic change, real policy implementation that limits/dissolves old infrastructure: actually these will enact change.
And honestly, policy can be complex, it's boring sometimes. (For my taste honestly. I hate reading bills.) So yeah, how to get average people involved with stuff besides sharing infographics and following trendy activists
Which are important too, don't get me wrong.

This means the obvious route toward actually doing something needs to be in the form of demanding real policy change - but this runs so much risk and stress. People could, um, like, pressure politicians? Local reps *and* major government big boys/girls/people whatever, who could put pressure on Congress and finally actually, ACTUALLY vote this out correctly, finally ending the free reign of lobbyists. Oh yeah - and the lobbying thing!! That has gotten our politicals so corrupt. I digressed again. What my age group *could* do is vote, yeah. Vote always! Get our friends to do to go forth for any voting and primaries and actually show the world - and these stuffy old politician type folks -- that climate change's solution is NOT a partisan/bipartisan type of argument

Furthermore, we must embrace tech. Innovation allows my group to connect on a far-more reaching mass communication capacity, that previously existed just in terms of legacy channels + corporations. Technology allows us to develop new clean energy solutions, too.

Finally, we need to support solutions. Like, truly commit. Donate to climate organizations, amplify indigenous voices in climate defense, pressure universities to divest assets like a portfolio/capital that they are earning an additional revenue stream - which helps the university, that allows students future success, coming at all detriment and ruin of the future for ALL PEOPLE . Okay yikez, getting way away again. Ultimately if something works, stick to with and encourage others to as well. Together! Teamwork. Okay I have no idea where I even was so let me finish. My point: my gen won't solve this if you simply 'recycle and buy eco" you guys have to band together!
Our choices is simple!
I think... that should be it.

topic: Write a 500-word essay about whether standardized testing is fair.
essay_text:
Standardized testing. A monolith of modern education, designed, supposedly, to level the playing field. But does it, really? Or are we simply trading real, nuanced assessment for something cold and fundamentally flawed? Depends, I guess.

Fair? Highly subjective. Standardized tests like the SAT simply measure a very limited slice of a student's potential. Skills honed for the test matter much more than innate raw academic talent that may otherwise blossom under more accommodating conditions. They privilege some while disadvantaging other, equally deserving, students.

Okay, like really think about it. Let's say, let's *really* say, a student comes from a low-income background. Their schools are chronically underfunded, meaning less access to experienced teachers, specialized resources or even the simple peace and quiet to study. They might also have this job. Lots of students have jobs. Balancing work and their lives and studies. Homework piling up, need to feed your cat/dog/baby sister  It is a lot. Can this student prep for the SAT with the same intensity as the child coming from a wealthy family whos got access to tutors; is going on intensive weekend workshops focused only and solely on that one exam; AND who probably doesnt have to worry about whether the lights are going to shut off or if theres food in the refrigerator? Hmmm?? And then what about students with learning disabilities, like dyslexia, are they really able to show all they all they can really doing?! No! Absolutely, categorically, unequivocally, not!!

See, all of these questions really do bring up what should be asked about it! Standardized testing also fails to account. Cultural biases in test questions contribute to a disadvantage. Even the way tests are designed assume a degree of a type of cultural that they *think* is a perfect human of a perfect understanding, or perfect cultural experiences  and yet so many people aren't in that place on our spectrum --. The time constraints, the emphasis on speed and rote memorization these favor students who are good at, well, taking tests. Think about it -- does being great or even good on standardized test mean that is the sole indicator of a great student? I don't always think it is, because test-taking isn't real comprehension skills -- so how is a score being the marker determining our futures to the things to come? Okay? Okay, I said that. But also does some score define the limits to ones talent; the future that awaits even! I just, like -- how, how can it work...? When you think about how people can rise against seemingly impossible barriers by making it -- I simply trail off.

Basically yeah. Uneven playing field created. Therefore, standardized unfair. That's my thoughts...I am feeling unsure because yeah -- it only gets me so far.

topic: Write a 500-word essay about whether standardized testing is fair.
essay_text:
Okay, here's a stab at an essay examining the fairness of standardized testing that meets the specific criteria laid out. It might jump around a bit as requestedmy bad in advance!. I will try!

Standardized tests. They're everywhere. Gatekeepers determining futures?

The core issue surrounding standardized testing rests on the very idea of standardization itself. Can any single, uniform test truly and fairly assess the diverse range of knowledge, skills, and aptitudes within a large population? Doubtful, to say the least! Think of background things, socioeconomic, educationalso much diversity exists. This standardization, while intended to create a supposedly level playing field, inevitably favors students from certain educational backgrounds and disadvantages others from resource deprived areas. It inherently neglects and fails individuals and minorities based upon cultural circumstance or a simple unfortunate scenario. It means.

Standardized tests purportedly offer objectivity, a cold and factual assessment of skillsthat's good in theory. No bias, supposedly. But objectivity itself doesn't equate automatically with fairness. The inherent problem becomes noticeable as they test cultural understanding when a subject like arithmetic requires pure numeric skill with nearly equal representation (unless you consider common core to have some faults I suppose?). After all cultural context hugely alters vocabulary of these important terms affecting the overall comprehension during testing procedures negatively affecting fairness criteria due to these cultural and lifestyle considerations! Furthermore standardization promotes teaching "to the test" which hurts students whose strength lies outside of test-taking skills. Okay yes they develop fundamental reading, grammar, problem solving and essay practices/skillsets. Yes these are valuable skills. Tests require discipline which is fantastic. These practices help! They do indeed. However it neglects individual creativity. What I mean by that isthere might be skills/thought that goes beyond the test. Creative problem solving or real world things. This is not captured by rote memorization...because teaching the test has very poor effect! Some educators are just looking for quick results (and yes they may be under great pressure due to administrative oversight regarding school's general assessment!). The students from privileged socio-economic status will always have unfair advantage from this set because not all educational sectors and school districts arent funded and resourced equally which provides this segment of the population the greater chance because funding allows tutors enrichment curriculum and college acceptance preparations...and on forever and ever leading people to get good grades, and they memorize... but not *knowing.*

And that brings things nearly to some resolution here: Standardized tests lack essential nuance which is such a critical step/consideretations!. The whole fairness Its really impossible when.

topic: Write a 500-word essay about whether standardized testing is fair.
essay_text:
Standardized testing. Fair? A complex question.

Many argue standardized tests offer a level playing field; that, ideally, they measure knowledge and ability impartially regardless of background or socioeconomic status. Sounds promising. The pro proponents assert that these tests are vital tools to assess educational effectiveness and assure there is accountability about, more specifically about holding schools to basic skills. To make any improvements whatsoever there has to be consistent scoring, some baseline everyone knows in order to mark gains or failings, and blah blah its really about measurable outcomes and not soft feelings. If anything this sounds pretty logical or I dont know about all of this stuff. This ensures kids aren't going through all the steps without making tangible advancement. Of course, that system requires all students begin with something approximating a level playing fieldor even close to! It implies equitable access to great schools, enough resources, and food or help with homework. And yet

But hold on a minute... The reality is far from that idealized vision really when taking a deep introspective glimpse into the real lives of real, actual students. What about income? Wealth disparity vastly influences educational opportunities. Wealth gives you tutors and prep courses. Disadvantaged schools often grapple  and this is a struggle for sure; they cant catch a decent breeze, metaphor alert alert! struggle against underfunding. Overcrowding. Lack of updated materials, overworked educators always pressed for funding and time management. Think about that kid in AP? Never getting what the public high gets so easily like access to tools in the classrooms? Then factor in standardized tests, too? I keep watching parents scream to the teacher at meetings demanding to know will Tims grade affect Ivy placement what kid out there lives and hopes to pass for the end of the course at the local high school will even see that pressure let alone deal with any access to good help?? These systemic inequities can directly impact performance as kids can access things better based based on their level of advantage in society because society seems to constantly reward them. And these high pressure performances measure everything so when they dont work out they weigh unfairly, with results possibly under reflecting underlying abilities. Cultural bias can play a significant role. One question, or an anecdote in social studies, etc. etc. it often seems more tailored, you guessed it friends back to students of mainstream culture! Can this even exist, truly or will culture bleed out of education at some stage I really feel. Not everyone lives, breathes, or studies everything or same or something!! Linguistic challenges, further complicate matters. It's not as clear as "one kid gets richer and becomes number 1 because there society says go go", even if it sounds like society wants it to be a direct link...

Ultimately, these assessments are flawed but a better form of assessment.... might require more than we give. To simply... assess. Is it even the purpose given the circumstances everyone goes through or society seems to offer?

topic: Write a 500-word essay about whether standardized testing is fair.
essay_text:
Okay, alright... Let's talk about standardized testing, shall we? You know, those delightful Scantron sheets and the joy of bubbling in A, B, C, or D... like anyone feels that much joy. The question whether these tests are actually *fair*... Well, that's the million-dollar question isn't it? Loaded question.

They're designed, supposedly, to level the playing field. Measure everyone on a single ruler. This I mean in theory, isn't terrible. But... what is fair truly?

Think about it this way. Do we really  and I actually mean REALLY truly  achieve an appley-to-appley type comparison to begin with? Students arrive at the testing center with different backgrounds. Some have private tutors. Others inherit test strategies practically alongside "baby words". Their parents prepare them, drill them, bribe them! How fair is *that*? What have the low-income kids got that comes close? Zip. Some struggle with test anxiety beyond anything. They cram so hard. Sleep poorly. Their own families add pressure they may buckle right there, under all that. Do tests measure grit? I feel some kind of pressure right now just considering all that they must be feeling in those crowded room with fluorescent, awful-y white lighting reflecting even more light back into their already pounding headaches. Also, different schools inherently provide different educational *quality*. Funding inequality in place. So like a kid from a private school taking Calculus while the public schoo kid just *gets* to *share* four old lab tables. Is the test equal  or even the potential of performance equal-- when their foundational preparation doesn't even have any equal starting point going into this all! That's clearly unbalanced. Tests penalize different learning styles, the kid too busy surviving poverty cannot have absorbed whatever "relevant things" these tests all seem so smugly convinced they manage to assess  you almost can't test at all without like testing out *that stuff as the testing part*: all of which only is a sliilliiiiitle scratch at the truth that testing also *demotes* learning and *demotes curiosity*. So no true chance of success when... right?! Oh darn I lost what I was saying.. oh yeh, wait, the unfairnesses!! Like, is fair that someone with Dyslexia will score on these narrow "must spit out answers that are there now" testing times as equal as a dude who sees all in perfect visual light! (Maybe my example choice aint ideal, there; its only example tho to illustrate!). In all, that equality gets so lost when so so much non"tested"-type background factors are at work when it happens at all. Argh so anyway... *therefore*, it just gets harder when they pretend that a good "score" equates somehow magically into perfect life and *perfect-human* success. I do wonder. Yes? What has value beyond all understanding, actually, is developing into the person that is exactly meant to be -- to have individuality. As such, we cannot allow uniforms! It can hurt a young person's perspective and attitude -- making the school feel much sadder in the end because what else is a school for besides getting a degree? I mean isn't is *also* the emotional development of new people, teaching them social skills and how people truly interact?!

Then you have to consider the economic aspect, and honestly, this is where it gets incredibly tricky and starts bending the whole argument like a weird pretzel made of moral and monetary stuff. Proponents will assert that uniforms help level the playing field no more kids getting bullied for not wearing the right brands, no visual cues that immediately scream "poor" or "wealthy." Sounds amazing, right? Because let's remember: these young people grow up to be *US*, each and every contributing member so it follows intuitively, and of basic logic -- helping these kids must pay off handsomely in the long-run! And therefore, leveling is good too, and *therefore* less bullying! Sounds idyllic. But hold on a moment. So the idea is "no rich labels"! Rich kids *who want to* make their lives flashy -- by wearing rich-stuff clothes. Now they can't and this reduces the bad of consumer-ism? This must result in people making judgements from a lack of that information -- creating *inferrable judgement*, which means there will simply arise different clues to find this judgement. For those from poorer circumstances this translates, obviously, into further harassment given the more creative ways to ferret out class divides and *harass* someone -- to take one very specific route! But the more common *inferrations about* the wealth you find, will, indeed change. Therefore -- just this entire levelling premise seems super-dodgy. And of questionable ultimate social value! So, I am still thinking it! Plus where does the money come in. They aint giving those things for 5 bucks people. Just another huge scam.

In summary... uniforms. Well, it's obviously complicated, and like, it turns out my first knee-jerk reaction might genuinely have, also, kind-of made a point maybe?

topic: Write a 500-word essay about a book that changed your perspective.
essay_text:
Okay, here we go. Ugh, this is due tomorrow?

Alright, the book. *The Grapes of Wrath* did it. Major perspective shift. Steinbeck. California. Dust Bowl. Profound.

It's about a family searching for a better life. The Joads. Oklahoma to California. Lost everything. Truly awful conditions. Powerful messages resonate even now.

Before reading Steinbeck's epic tale, I, like, understood the Great Depression on kind of an academic, far-removed level. Dates that should be known, basic conditions impacting the social zeitgeist that had important, cascading reverberated through to WWII, yada, yada, ya. Economic downturn. Banks failed. Farms failing and people couldnt do anything. Know history's repeating tendencies so maybe people should vote a certain... Okay, back to the prompt! It's completely different when you're presented with this incredibly intimate look. Steinbeck just throws you right into the Okie experience. He makes you *feel* it. The poverty is thicksuffocating, almost. And there's this underlying sense of dignity throughout even in absolute moments of degradation because the Joas had no recourse. A great sadness can overcome any reader. You see not dates as symbols but a family working through strife even when there exists no solution due to powers greater existing as invisible forces to control a people through capitalism. It was not very nice what companies did (and still are doing but much more so at th eitme) in our country.

 Ma Joad particularly stands out in my mind. She's the absolute keystone in the family. Keeping the entire crew together despite insurmountable odds of hardship that almost appear biblically amplified in scale sometimes. The scene where they cross the desert--horrible. Losing Grandma. I even gasped, right in from of everyone reading the text, and the sheer force almost sent my soul floating to heaven through the pages.

Steinbeck gets you to question notions. Makes you see beyond the surface in terms of who is human and why those deemed not are treated that way as though not real people; to the average, even though the same struggles of existence apply. Why *these* people had such issues. It challenged pre-conceived socio-political notions about social constructs. I never realizedwell, not truly realizedas an intimate form, those displaced folks as so inhuman they were being treated. Made the idea to not take them into certain territories for they spread diseases and bring general riff raff. Awful rhetoric I only learned when delving deeper after finishing the overall textual themes and impact of Steinbeck, even today!

Anyway it just yeah made me way more compassionate. That it does that a bit, though the specifics evade how. History wasn't as I was told...

Alright maybe I could get that into an *A*-. Gotta stop rambling! One last read.

topic: Write a 500-word essay about a book that changed your perspective.
essay_text:
Alright, gotta bang this thing out. The book that, like, really shifted my perspective? *Siddhartha* by Hermann Hesse. Yep. That's the one.

Quick read, small book. Massive impact  or at least for me anyway because coming-of-age stories typically do have the ability to shift someones perspectives on life and everything. The idea, though, it really stuck with me. 

It's about... um... this guy, Siddhartha (duh!). And he's searching for enlightenment. Simple enough, right? He's got it made. He's clearly the most spiritually equipped person for miles. Leaves his privileged life of caste responsibilities to become an ascetic. Almost starves to death, in fact. Joins this group and decides their interpretation is wrong.

And its this entire journey. And thats sort of the whole deal I feel like, right? A complete departure from normal traditions when searching for ways toward wisdom. Finding the "better way." He first ditches his family for a super strict religious group, then ditches ***them*** because reasons  I cant quite recall, but it felt *right*. All makes sense. He learns from the Buddha (kinda), finds out the Buddha isnt the right way *for him*. The point is this guy, this dude, wants enlightenment so badly he has to experience... everything. And here's the real kicker, right, even in thinking you're right, everyone is on different perspectives and journeys toward improvement if improvement in itself exists or provides anything positive but rather is a part of the journey within itself through perception leading to potential destruction for one to grow further past. Which gets at the core belief I've now come to value so deeply as that life isn't about doctrine, instead, your journey through life depends explicitly on individual choice and change as only the singular subjective experience can lead to any sort of purpose and truth. No pre-packaged answers.

Eventually, (skipping a lotta stuff here, riverside old-timer blah, sensual awakening with a Kamala that eventually has the Siddhartha named son of our main hero. Eventually his son is too stuck-up, but whatever). He realizes knowledge...knowing and experience...is what helped him grow from these experiences not any adherence toward preconceived notions or ideas with how something was or how something shouldve necessarily have been. As opposed to having "knowledge", experiencing things for yourself allows you to grow... some stuff.... basically, like, you have to DO things and not memorize things for them count -- and Siddhartha, in the end, learned some stuff for true because, even though it might seem pointless even the "mistraes" helped grow. To, eventually again  learn more effectively in his quest toward betterment within spirituality to, quite possibly become like, a vessel for uh hmmm. Yeah, I like that read anyway.

So... Yeah, *Siddhartha*. Read it. It'll expand your mind.

topic: Write a 500-word essay about a book that changed your perspective.
essay_text:
Ugh, okay. I guess I have to actually *do* this essay. Alright, lets see: a book that changed my perspective... that's broad. 

"Fahrenheit 451." Classic. Obvious choice, probably what Ms. Periwinkle *wants* us to say. But, honestly? Before reading it, I just zoomed past all those "books are knowledge" cliches. It really did a number on me.

I always liked stories. Never burned books. Seemed odd/dumb that someone *would*.

Ray Bradbury's chilling portrayal of a bookless, thoughtless future made me reassess everything though. It isn't about appreciating "facts," like Ms. P keeps droning on. No. The power comes from wrestling with complex ideas, developing your own arguments. The book illustrated just howmalleable society is. It portrayed how complacency and the suppression of dissenting voices could contribute a dangerous societal trend. A trend away from independence. Independence from not knowing something. People will blindly latch on to whatever idea is floating about, as society does get dumbed down at random times and the ideas get dumbed down along with it and once its done thats sort of how you start a mob. If something becomes popular suddenly you always kind of jump against the idea, but whatever. Like, Mildred is constantly glued to her "parlor walls." She really isn't happy. Montag is deeply unsettled by books! Montag's initial aversion highlights their potential to disrupt shallow happiness and challenge the status quo. Isn't just *having* the information eitherremember when Montag actually did steal a book from and he tried actually *reading* something while he was on the subway and all of this insane nonsense happened? I would get crazy motion sickness too if loud commercials screamed in my ear about 'Denhams Dandy Dental Detergent," yeesh! Anyway that part reminded me to actively fight brain melt. To use the information from stories and not waste any of time. Books like "Fahrenheit 451" can, yeah, show us, that we do sometimes already know about ideas or stuff, but maybe if we actively choose against the ideas, we aren't really *thinking.* Its not as simple is liking different things like soda and soda, or, like how kids from high school all love different colors in their outfit but that's really sort of the deepest thought they've had because they've been too concerned with trends instead. The point is if things make you so confused, then it becomes apparent, which becomes some thinking to do and it becomes what the plot is and what the deeper meaning of an allegory for mankind really means here as the future may lay ahead. Which brings some enlightenment and realization about the meaning.

Bradbury showed how easily people, and societies, allow freedoms to erode. We want to fit in. Maybe more than we want to think. Maybe, then, that's why Bradbury makes a good argument for the fact that individuality becomes all you've got to keep an outlook on things!

Books can open. Oh god where even -- okay, yes. Books. They can open your mind and offer new ways of seeing things. Maybe even change yeah... the future... or something.

topic: Write a 500-word essay about a book that changed your perspective.
essay_text:
Alright, gotta do this. Need to write about a book. A perspective-changing book. Um... Which one? Deadline is *looming*. Think, think. Okay, *The Plague* by Albert Camus. It's the one. Gonna write about it. Here goes nothing.

It hit hard, man. Real hard. So bleak but... hopeful? Yeah, hopeful *in* the bleakness. That's the crux of it, I think.

Changed... everything. Made me rethink stuff. You know?

*The Plague* is, obviously, about a plague hitting the city of Oran. Shocking, right? Camus meticulously details the descent of the city into isolation and the desperate measures people take, or often fail to, in the face of mass *death*. Anyway, the beauty within this narrative actually wasn't always the descriptions as he sort of tells, not shows(too much!). His central metaphor for the absurdity of living or for our fight against the inevitable is striking regardless. Anyway, Oran slowly closes up under the weight of this crisis brought down by vermin, both mental and actual-- and while everything else decays due to the overwhelming forces that are pushing from inside like mold, humanity does not completely collapse. Like what does it cost people to care for each other when doing only benefits oneself? To care just a little... And there's Dr. Rieux, just doing his *job*, for goodness sake, trying to keep people alive in a situation he can't magically "fix." Same goes for Rambert, the journalist just stuck looking from the outside in, trying to get back to someone he might never ever get back to because that love has passed him by unbeknownst and/or unknown -- anyway who just cares about him. But you see it also in people like Tarrou, who makes it all so much easier, who are dedicating their lives to things better themselves because without people dedicated towards building, this world would only cave from the slightest breeze(or plague if you care for some direct metaphors-- like that sentence right their? so good!) But beyond the specifics -- the sickness -- the way the book tackles such gigantic subjects like humanitys shared battles against pain; what those values can give when no alternatives exist-- It made me see things clearer? Like mortality, not to harp but its scary out there knowing for so long you can always slip down there at anytime whether its because someone decided they where more important etc? The sense about living something great is often that sense. Like what's my duty, even if nobody is ordering me so? It changes the outlook; made smaller, stupid crap seem exactly as I described. Even without plagues raging! The whole *thing*.

I guess what I am getting at is facing bad times reveals truth. In everyone. It reveals everything or is meant to... but what can you when face to face, except be human. At the end, you can only keep at it yourself, so theres.
