topic: Write a 500-word essay about climate change and what your generation can do.
essay_text:
Okay, climate change. Big problem. Generation's problem? Super big.

The polar bears are sad! What about future generation though, not just the bears. This isn't just about recycling plastic grocery bags (although please, for everyone, recycle them). The scope? Massive. Earth at risk. We need to do SOMETHING.

Alright, let's justdive into that SOMETHING. What *can* we do? Apathy's tempting. Totally understandable to curl into a little ball of existential dread and binge-watch Netflix until the ice caps have melted directly onto your sofa, but like, wouldn't that sofa be soggy and gross, though? So maybe action, not despair. So. Our power lies, arguably, in a two-pronged approach, leaning heavily, for my argument at hand, on pushing for systemic change through activism and informed consumerism, but also doing little important things at the homefront, when time seems possible.

Seriously, think about voting. The current climate change narrative hinges on political policies that encourage change versus discouraging action such by supporting the fossil-fuel industries in very detrimental ways. The political will we can create that by rallying behind politiciansthose who actually understand the ramifications scientists keep laying out over and over and advocate seriously for renewable policies, and, most importantly, *listening* to real science in this world that's filled with a cacophony of questionable studies and paid influencers. This is a call for a new cohort of people, new ideas, not same-old corporate pockets. And, let's face facts, it extends beyond simply "voting blue" versus "staying deep ingrained red", it's examining *local* representation which are extremely impactful, the candidates who actually walk the walked instead of people only claiming actions of goodness via grand speechification because you have to check to credentials. A great many politicians can talk great talking actions and have really, the *smallest* amount of doing completed. Truly! Activism means calling your representatives too. Annoying them with demands related to more bike line offerings in your town! Pushing for solar panels over coal in local energy grids which are more and more crucial right now too. We want the environment. It leads to so much greatness because the more active the city is, we, as inhabitants participate for healthier bodies and mindsets too which has such a phenomenal domino effect for societal well-being when things go right and there ends now here now.
Like getting the word out! Climate conversations are too stuffy usually! And how is the average voter to find the courage to find their voting voice and make any action related difference right at the place's genesis? Ugh. Inform yourselves but also get creative in getting through to others. Make art about it, like poems AND cool TikTok? Seriously, spread solid information and also keep pushing, always always pushing.

Reduce. Reuse. Really actually *think* about what the hell you're buying and the impacts embedded within those product's entire life cycle, from creation to delivery all the way down the garbage dump, if that. Fast fashions obviously a massive pit so choosing sustainable more ethical clothing. Reduce your water usage. Try eating less meat, just start with incorporating a vegetarian entree once a week...

Okay. Look. It seems hopeless right now. But is doing "something, someday," so important. Okay? Whew It is all we can actually possibly do with only the smallest sense of control during a world in its crisis. This does make up for everything.

Instead of denial, cynicism becomes an extremely unfortunate but sometimes almost seductive position to fall into. The scope of damage honestly renders much of the conversation overwhelming -- not something simple and accessible to grasp for daily people that might not honestly have the education, the money, leisure access that allows engagement in the issues -- people who can only work towards feeding their own families every honest morning. It't more or less proven that big names that can show a commitment that means a difference would likely get support. The thing for sure is... our dollar actually does talk and our voice is pretty amplified and big nowadays. We arent naive. Understand performative action from genuine engagement which gets past the public. See which corps actually put in the work beyond just marketing the environmental efforts out of their PR depts. Be ruthless, hold accountable corporations, governments, organizations too. Voting counts, activism, using our resources -- all count!

We have the power to shape the future, influence decisions, support and do real important work with genuine change. It requires moving! Requires not quite standing by any long but... alright gotta hand finished, professor is... wait, is class literally in..

topic: Write a 500-word essay about climate change and what your generation can do.
essay_text:
Okay, deep breaths... climate change essay time. Gotta get this done.

Listen. Climate change. Bad. Our planet is warming, and the consequences are already barreling down on us like a runaway train hopped up on espresso and a bad attitude. The facts: indisputable!

Rising sea levels. Uh oh! Extreme weather events are also on the rise. A major "yikes." We face potential food shortages, mass migrations, social unrest. Okay, so basically a real-world disaster movie, starring us. But nobody wants to see it, because really scary.
***
Alright, Generation Z. Were the generation that somehow, despite all our student loan debt and the collapsing housing market, also got saddled--somehow inexplicably saddled--with saving the world. So how do we even deal with that? I mean, come on. Isn't that totally unfair? Shouldn't the Boomers take full responsibility for all of those plastics bags and lead factories? And those giant cars they use? It used to be simple with climate change and say switch to metal water bottles, or maybe bike to work. Very surface-level eco-movements! But the issue is way larger, so now so many youth climate activists call this greenwashing and perform actions that can be viewed as harmful, which they believe can bring about true long term radical change. Some argue protesting at board meetings with large banks is harmful for the very large bankers holding onto the bags of money. After all where there's finance funding the destruction on Earth, somebody needs some "payback." Who knows if the youth-led non-profits will last long anyways-- they dont get all that funding.

And I think the whole consumption piece, while definitely part of the issue needs to be like really expanded upon, if that make sense, because buying "eco-friendly" stuff that doesn't mean solving anything when massive corporations cause seventy-one percent of emissions  that needs the focus. Oh also how we consume entertainment matters as well! Should every influencer have a private jet? Can we find ways to reduce emissions? Those digital subscriptions or video reels. Wow thinking through all that is enough!

Like, yeah, the science textbooks, the lectures at protests. Those are important; information crucial But translating information into action? Much tougher than it looks, for those still learning. Finding true large scale, community organized collective activism?
That calls for really radical changes on an unprecedented economic as well political spectrum for the environment -- to make way for solutions and mitigation or adaption, for this new wave. It entails rethinking capitalism (gulp!), our political leadership (double gulp!). But who's honestly going to invest the real manpower! Now, with that very large disclaimer about scale and change... Okay. What *can* we do? Speak-up like. Start small.
***

Point is we can do many many different actions to slow climate change (to perhaps a halt!!!) , our planet depends on urgent solutions to come from Gen Z and even older generation to stop its demise. The essay should've expanded each important point really but! Okay, the clock ticking down now

Ultimately our work will just have to depend what direction as a country, we ultimately work and change! That's my closing thought!

topic: Write a 500-word essay about climate change and what your generation can do.
essay_text:
Okay, deep breaths. Climate change. Super important blah blah blah. My generation. Pressure's on, right? Let's get this done.

topic: Write a 500-word essay about whether standardized testing is fair.
essay_text:
Okay, so fairness. Big question, right? Standardized tests everyone takes them. Seemingly, it should be unbiased. Should be. Is it, though?

The problem: advantage. Some kids are simply at an advantage. Resources, tutors, perfectly sharpened number-two pencils for days so they don't accidentally shade outside a bubble and lose a crucial point whichlook, Im getting off track. My point is some kids get practice tests. Expensive ones. Whole courses where they teach you HOW to take the test. No ones teaching Timmy who sleeps on the floor of his moms tiny apartment that has mice scampering around at night how to bubble faster and more beautifully. Seriously... what advantage does success on a standardized test truly reflect if that measurement only indicates whether someone has a personal tutor teaching them better testing tactics after regular school every Monday through Thursday for a semester so that when presented bubble choice A-D that can differentiate nuances in English usage not even expected to write or utter during day-to-day social life, someone isn't just familiar at how questions generally proceed forward, rather completely mastering the test beyond just grasping the material being assessed. That just inherently can't be fair. I think tests in this capacity test privilege above anything else about students and their future potentials. And if only some are actually allowed this leg-up the measurement starts seeming like it never would serve our needs or indicate academic progress from someone taking it on an equal starting ground because no person actually takes our standardized tests starting in anything close to this, making any score indication of mastery nothing in itself. Does this make them unfair as a default? Are biases inherently unavoidable as they measure things within a testing scope which, within itself, does not capture the individual intricacies of any of the individual and diverse students presented these quizzes? Or does it ultimately depend on what consequences result after each evaluation to either reward each student fairly? Fairnessreally have consequences or it wouldn't bear a great impact on academic, social advancement for testing high versus failing it altogether for a fair amount of people. And while certain people may do just fine to study once the test has shown back grades, how does an actual learning outcome change when certain institutions take these scores as everything to judge a student for life rather than using alternative opportunities for said people within more advantageous means and other metrics of student and academic performances than through bubbling through an exam?

Standardize test = wealth test? Maybe.

Thinking about things that way. Then *maybe* ditching isnt likecompletely crazy. The best solutions are almost always a bit more nuanced. There needs to be more options available. Alternatives to, or revisions.

topic: Write a 500-word essay about whether standardized testing is fair.
essay_text:
Okay, deep breaths. Let's churn this thing out. Standardized testing, fair or foul? Big question clouding everything about education right now. Seems problematic.

On the one hand, you need *some* way to measure student learning against a common standard. Otherwise chaos. Is standardized the *right* way though? Probably not, but easier. Standardized easier. We like easy, unfortunately.

However, let's delve into the tangled reasons why standardized tests reek of deep unfairness, considering. The inherent issue slumps to a focal shift to standardized test taking techniques, prioritizing tactics over comprehension and actual synthesis. Students end up prepared *simply* to perform and ace *these specific standardized assessments*. School curriculums warp when driven by the necessity for good statistics reflecting proper benchmarks, especially to be able to hold on to future income potential by attracting students and funding from a limited budget provided to school systems from the state. That creates more problems that you would have not foreseen like less money going to subjects beyond the standardized test subjects. Thus, teaching itself is reoriented: emphasis switches from enriching instruction to narrow concentration preparing only for performance on the given metrics of these specific, soul-obliterating tests. And, it should also be noted that that all falls disproportionately onto students, especially the underprivileged populations of lower income students and ethnic minority communities who are dependent on the already poorly funded system. Like, if a richer family has a tutor, they can focus the regular school material but also ace the test to get into university. The poorer kids end up just barely preparing themselves *only* for the tests, resulting in lowered long term benefits. What about a passion of math? The humanities? Artistic interest! So the very testing themselves, these pillars promising impartial judgments are revealed only as structural obstacles holding up and further developing uneven structures. I lose myself there in anger, sorry back to the original statement here -- standardized is unfair at its heart.

Okay, so, um, where was I? Test scores and unfair stuff impacting performance from outside. It kind of stacks up. This leads to huge frustration on multiple levels, not limited to just the students like I was talking about earlier. Families and administration deal with additional weight to get more successful statistics, but in failing to achieve this the schools themselves end up more disadvantaged like it is intended by these tests because isn't higher ranking equal to attracting kids and gaining more funding? I'm going down another tangential rabbit hole basically it boils down to inequitable for sure. Education suffers the consequences, or the kids do? Both suffer. The end gets blurrier and blurrier in assessing how much each element goes its part.

In conclusion really feels unachievable, but whatever. It just seems less than ideal how this whole measurement process unfolds. The standardized thing and all.

topic: Write a 500-word essay about a book that changed your perspective.
essay_text:
Okay, let's do this. Time to crank out this essay. It's, uh, on how a book changed your perspective, you said? Right. Here goes nothing!

Certain books linger. They worm their way into your understanding. And then? Boom. Everything shifts. A subtle rearrangement of the mental furniture.

Some just make you think. *This* one got in my bones though. A real shake-up. Perspective profoundly altered. Here's how.

Ugh, okay. So, the book that really messed with my head  in a good way! Mostly.  was "A Sand County Almanac" by Aldo Leopold. Mr. Leopold. Sounds aristocratic, doesn't it with a name like Aldo? Ugh, focus! Right, Leopold. We actually *briefly* touched on him in my ENVS 101 class, Introduction to Environmental Science, remember, that snooze-fest with Dr. Arbuthnot who droned on about um sustainable development models? Yeah that course. Like, the *one* lecture. Oh well. We had to analyze, I think, some fragment of his idea that "Land is now, finally becoming something judged good as long as someone obtains private profit within the system of economics when 'land' is something for it's own moral value of preserving," it's probably in a volume called *Ethics of Leopold Volume.* Anyway. My mind boggled, thats true. That lecture didn't sink in all the real reason, I would say. Not Like Leopold does. So *before* I'd read "A Sand County Almanac," you know; land rights, conservation were kinda abstract to me. Words. Ideas, mostly. I agreed with concepts; "protecting nature?" Totally, do it; "endangered turtles?" Sure seems like there are many turtles to exist forever. Like, logging? Whatever, just like...plant trees and don't do it I suppose! Things I heard from Captain Planet. Basically it's abstract stuff one hears the news and is basically agreeable towards; and really only think about when things come up, of course-- not every free 60 second or after brushing my teeth or whatever. I just had no personal investment, none, none no.

It's when he *starts writing like a human,* rather than just these scientific terms from a dry lecturer dude, that a different relationship starts. He makes you watch deer browse. He tells stories that can hit. He speaks of things from hunting- while having great knowledge how even good intent makes consequences. The point being--- oh crap, have I even said the core ideas enough? The LAND it itself, not just the resources or commodity of the things, just... are worthy of existing! And not just because the deer would be fun to shoot either, of course. Anyway... I am bad at getting to points here clearly-

But it gets me thinking about legacy, so its kind of beautiful-- but also it gets me thinking maybe... maybe I didn't summarize it as much as a summary because he is getting to things in a meandering, human, way like someone thinking outside your car or by a camp like you yourself.

 Anyway I definitely need sleep now, time to end. Ugh essay finished--ish. I really should look at that Dr. Arbuthnot thing for the actual title now... too long; and too sleepy now-- submission time-- hope I'm not out on the land rights myself after how crap that was.

topic: Write a 500-word essay about a book that changed your perspective.
essay_text:
Okay, okay. Deep breaths. Let's get this done.

I guess it's *Howards End* by E.M. Forster. It's kinda cliche, I know. English major problems. But for real, it actually got to me. I genuinely went into it expecting something dry and boring (brutal, right?). Because, well, classics. Wrong. The Edwardian Era in England was pretty interesting if explored through Forster's prose style and attention toward character development in the Schlegel's and Wilcox's households. Like, mind blown for *this* girl haha.

The plot, briefly: two very different families intersect, clash heads... then there's a will, a house, love, and tragedy. All of it happens with subtle commentary on social classes. Boom: that could be a summary. But there is so much more layered themes within the novel as well... okay. So many themes. But I only need one specific concept right?

The big aha came with the idea of ""connection." That's it. Forster hammers them relationship, and the problems stemming from disconnection, throughout all the novels pages like a blacksmith uses many various shapes of metals and forging process - each creating distinct products with a cohesive theme of labor. I think the full quote is, "Only connect!" Remember what Professor Armistead read in our section on Victorian Literature? That thing from... ugh. *The Condition of the Working Class in England* by... Engels! Maybe. Ugh can't remember! All those German guys meld together!! Point is some German Socialist had a point too, it would seem and so like these people are dealing with the transition from rural England to something very modern. Factories. Inequality. The whole deal. Not really connected anymore either.

And it totally spoke to me after class because even in *my* world, which in today's day is SOOOO interconnected (ironic, innit?), everyone still misses that feeling. Scrolling all-day; nobody *really* talks. We hide behind screens or curated highlight reels showing only the amazing moments that are far from truthful but create a false sense of happiness and connectivity that seems within grasp, if only more likes were achieved! How are any of us different the "telegrams and anger" of old Edwardians according E.M? Technology feels designed mostly divide the population, or the digital divide seems deeper amongst many social spaces. We can post opinions online, without thought or empathy, creating even more social discord from that lack to face communication amongst peers, co-workers. Forster showed me how that yearning for genuine, meaningful contact is a human need and also how hard to fully obtain since as he implies, social and lifestyle differences and opinions create the discord in the connection people make through different aspects like art and money. The rich don show off and look better than the poor! But then the less wealthy grow bitter! Everyone misses the point of art-which to connect and heal those feelings. Makes such sense to think how his thoughts could hold just as well centuries later. Wow, time just does that huh? Anyway. It reminds us to put real work in those core relationships or whatever. So good idea, probably worth putting on this blasted Lit paper. Maybe I'm just tired.

Okay, done, yeah? *submit*.

topic: Write a 500-word essay about a book that changed your perspective.
essay_text:
Okay, gotta get this done. Deep breaths. Essay time. Let's do this. The book... hmmm... *The Dispossessed* by Ursula K. Le Guin. Yeah, that's it.

Le Guin painted futures. Radically challenging societal norms. I dug that.

It messed with my brain concerning capitalism and Anarchism. Complex. Left me rethinking everything.

The book follows Shevek an extremely smart physicist physicist living on Anarres which is a tiny little moon that has been colonized by... well essentially philosophical anarchists who left a resource depleted and extremely Capitalist planet  it's an interesting set up and the two societies have almost no engagement with each other which makes the first interaction of this very very bright physicists incredibly impactful and charged I think what really got my gears turning was the depiction of Anarres itself its not some perfect utopian vision, Oh, no it struggles with its own weird forms of social oppression, even while trying to maintain. a deeply principled collective mindset, there are problems with resource distribution which lead to power struggles I seem to recall a supplementary reading that Professor Davis threw at us like week three something to the effect. A brief little blurb, it was The Irrelevant Mandate: Compulsory Sanitation and Water Rationing in Protracted Utopias." It explained it far better! It just painted a perfect encapsulation of some major problems she identified -- *that's why you need to make the correct and informed argument to avoid these problems!* Wait, what was it? From a volume on, yeah, Post Occupancy Dystopian Literature." Man. That woman LOVES her some niche subjects... Anyways, It highlighted real-world examples, and so then Le Guin demonstrated them so vividly within Anarres specifically its rigidness and sometimes just frustrating inefficiency it shows the characters striving but often feeling conflicted between the idealized vision and the realities of material want... which leads them to like adopt behaviors that sort of contradict their deeply held beliefs, or at least challenge them constantly -- So yes it's not a utopia its not at all but it is an exploration of how maybe. you live in society. I think that was something which felt, revolutionary, especially within my more closed-off Capitalist mindsets up until that point now seeing Anarres gave a better and real representation rather than the often perfect depictions of Anarchist societies. Realism always rules eh! And so Shevek goes and so shevek goes to Urras -- that is pretty cool because the contrasts she sets up between the collectivist principles and values. and this money obsessed society  yeah, that whole dynamic. It's so. Freaking. Good!. Sorry I gotta stop, its getting long- windded.. It changed my understanding though

Okay basically it just showed. nuances. Complexities in systems but... I think I got lost sorry. I need to just sleep. Gonna turn this in. Whew! Essay done. I hope whatever train of thought, at least loosely communicates. And at least will award the necessary marks!!!

topic: Write a 500-word essay about a book that changed your perspective.
essay_text:
Okay, here we go. Gotta get this done.

Neil Gaimans *American Gods* totally warped my view of, well, pretty much everything. Before, I had this solid picture of the world. Sort of. Now? Giant question mark hanging over my head attached to even bigger question marks. Everything I *thought* was real, stable suddenly seemedmalleable. Less of a fixed point. More ofsand?

Basically, the book flipped some internal switch in brain-meats and made me question deeply held assumptions. About belief. About power. Most strikingly, however, its discussion on globalization had me rethinking capitalism through a metaphysical lens (yuck...)

Okay, so here's the *whole* deal the more I started to really think about it: "gods", in this case, embody collective will  which gets weaker as things move on  especially in capitalism... Think brand name value of Nike; a form of new god in Gaimans thinking? At the very core of the book lurks such a scary idea: Gods are born for an extremely important time and must compete in the modern-day landscape for devotion. They die when forgotten. Then like, that forces the reader, AKA ME, and ideally the entire global economy maybe, to grapple to define ourselves *less* rigidly which seems counter-intuitive I feel. Because *American Gods* isn't as simple as "new versus old" it becomes "fluid versus ossified". Remember that whole "culture melts faster than the ice caps"? Okay, not *those* ice caps per se, but rather a general idea of historical and cultural understanding or heritage. Gulp. You know in class that paper on globalization that we, *think*, maybe, potentially (tired at this point) 'read' I *think* it touched the same concerns that also talked about a kind of... homogenizing force working to dismantle cultural traditions-- It was this obscure paper by some Lithuanian theorist whose name honestly escapes my mind *but* Gaiman's vision, by presenting literal gods clashing over belief and attention (which again, ultimately powers their lives if those beliefs *persist*), really drove home how delicate existence is? Sorry, but is 'devotion as gasoline' analogy super reductive? No. Okay I did NOT need to give in, time is a commodity! Gaiman actually pushes his ideas further when Shadow (a protagonist) must come a lot harder to his actual truth or belief when surrounded by such chaos, right? This also serves maybe, perhaps as this sort of roadmap when facing cultural anxiety due to a global, dare I say 'homogenizable' capital, and perhaps helps an individual discover a new truth? Well... Maybe also find out for yourself I can't carry such heavy philosophical implications when working for hours tonight.

Ultimately all comes undone. If belief, or investment, in a system is what causes that particular system  *a civilization based gods-per-whatever* or ***capital society predicated on product devotions/marketing or even something much worse like a politician***  to thrive. My perspective has been irrevocably altered. Maybe because I think I forgot the question? What were we suppose to be analyzing anyway? Sorry. Got caught thinking.

topic: Write a 500-word essay about a book that changed your perspective.
essay_text:
Okay, okay, gotta do this essay. "The book that changed my perspective"...ugh. Sleep would be better. But deadlines, am I right?
<!--stackedit_data:
eyJoaXN0b3J5IjpbLTEwMzIzMDY2MTVdfQ==
-->

The book? *Siddhartha* by Hermann Hesse. Simple story. Big impact.

Really made you think. Definitely more impacting than some of the lectures.

Okay, so like I was saying. *Siddhartha* isn't some crazy complex narrative. It's actually relatively short, which frankly was GREAT when I first picked it upprocrastinadoing (yes that'sn a portmanteau combining procrastinating while doing something productive, look into it. Okay but um, distractions). Hesse basically tells the story of a guy, name's you guessed it? Siddhartha, yeah. Who essentially bounces around between different spiritual teachers and philosophies looking for *something*. That's basically its whole plot reduced as barebones if necessary. And like it begins with him frustrated with Brahman life and then that's literally his exact trajectory of abandoning religious gurus, trying the purely material enjoyments of life the pleasure of a courtesan, and later wealth. Like its always that exact same pattern for pretty much the entirely of that story.

And the thing is that the appeal, while boringly rote on paper, has amazing merit on execution as what that experience teaches you is more of what the end result, a better life or understanding. Remember, he achieves Enlightenment finally sitting by that holy bank to be with the Ferrie men but who, but with whom... the point is not following THE path. Anyway, so like initially Siddhartha gets into life with ascetic Samanas. Trying a path, so serious, you see their devotion only for him to give it and become... what? A disciple of Gotama with perfect rules for life and thinking for oneself? Then once, again in time repeating the same process from earlier in the passage of chapters, finding passion the perfect answer? No...

We 'deconstruct,' is what Dr. Epstein called it, the ideal of absolute truth through the novel - like that weird papyrus fragment we had to read on early Jainist epistemology, you know, that debate with "conditional yes"? That *nothing* truly describes the Absolute, even enlightenment concepts.

Sorry I keep trailing to things that trigger some slight memory--wait, the river! That's something to cover, I completely abandoned it now. No no no no wait... ugh the bells. Point is: its about the journeys, maybe? The different lenses. And Siddhartha rejects other paths; because nobody can become or walk in this other life but to embody them for merely, and quite honestly by his own right, a simple imitation. Siddhartha cannot use Gotama's ways; how much more true might our case our own be that we learn that while there are better thinkers what we're able to put into, not being told how to walk that path itself, gives you so much muchness for everything.

The river, reflecting every journey he makes with the whole wisdom of it I can remember it more now

Ultimately changed things by showing Truth, as clich that sounds, isn't single but perspective, as much love is the key for everything from the beginning or when something starts but from there is the matter when, and with you when

Ok I'm done.

topic: Write a 500-word essay about climate change and what your generation can do.
essay_text:
Okay, alright, focus. Climate change essay. Gen Z. Got it. Lets do this.

Its a giant problem. Seriously HUGE. Like, bigger-than-Mount-Everest big. Were all gonna feel it. That sucks.

And it's on *our* shoulders. No pressure, right?! Pretty much the entire world's future resting on whether or not we can like, actually band together and fix... everything. Fun!

Look, alright - I remember in Global Issues classwas it September or October?reading like, a summary, kind of like a digest maybe?, of a scientific opinion piece from "The Australasian Journal of Disaster and Trauma Studies", remember *that*? Ugh. Anyway. It vaguely talked about how younger generations, despite carrying increased knowledge of climate issues, are often paralyzed by something they politely call "environmental fatalism"basically believing that no matter what we do as individuals because the thing is already basically on autopilot, spiraling out of control and our contribution kind of really won't matter and so, the motivation... well...it fades, so we gotta kinda look inside but ALSO to really large structural and legislative shifts or everything gets bleak and we'll just start spiraling in an, uuh, different kind of unhelpful thing.

So what CAN we like, DO? Beyond recycling rigorously because I've already internalized that feeling...that I *should* be in my daily habits. And not drinking from plastic water bottles which, BTW, I always spill anyway which contributes *to* the thing. I think like, advocating for policy. Pestering electeds about climate laws and shit; THAT feels crucial despite seeming abstract while I can't even organize my pantry how is my stupid self gonna *organize the nation,* *cough*.

Okay, lets go bigger. Like rethinking consumption? Can we even do THAT right?! I need my avocado toast but then THAT'S gonna ruin and deplete soil elsewhere so can only imagine how complex addressing our other forms of conspicuous spending is. Boycords of companies known for environmental destruction. Educate each other, ESPECIALLY because sometimes I actually find that adults AREN'T completely well informed which seems a little nutty and maybe its our special job - the only ones still paying attention when those above us don't even care enough from their ivory structures because nothing in it to gain directly (and, in some horrific-case scenarions - lose something instead...a thought too despair heavy). AND advocating for alternative means; not necessarily just what is asked or the surface answers given to us but to keep looking, too like *finding out which sources actually* **have** solid info which, tbh, it is freaking *dense*. Because if everyone keeps telling 20 little actions of this-or-that it still kinda looks a lot like that fatalism when the truth is far complex that individual guilt even gets *unproductive*. Sheesh if any adults ever realize we get this stuff...

So, yeah... basically fighting the apathy... and figuring out the BEST, EFFECTIVE strategies.... to actually fight climate change somehow and with an extra focus on where personal and global come intersecting and really... *something important* is *found*....because...?....something....uh....yeah. We *can*.

Okay, Okay, let's do this. This is, like, SO due tomorrow. Climate change, ugh. Scary stuff. But, hey, we can do something maybe...sort of!

Our generationwe face a behemoth. A climate crisis. Rising sea levels. Extreme weather events escalating seemingly every year. It's overwhelming, honestly. But denial? Totally not the answer... obviously.

Reducing our carbon footprint! Sounds good right!? Individual actions matter, I guess. Okaybut what *specifically* can *we* like YOU & ME *actually DO*. It is so daunting as heck, and feels we're small! Here it *goes*, what this essay can *try* and solve...

Okay - So what can *I actually talk* about right now?? Gah, okay focus.

Ummm, things my teachers said in class??... Hmm... I kinda, vaguely, *remember* my Environment Studies - teach. She made us read this (long boring!) academic, paper about this concept "Participatory Adaptation Modeling"... Yeah, I kinda get something out of the *fuzzy haze* in there!

Here me *out!* Here's a thing -

Like if one doesn't fully "grok" that *deep nerdy* context of things... (a 1970s academic source no 1 is quite bothering to deeply follow!). "Participatory Adaptation Modeling," to just say like, is really all about empowering communities! Bringing together, different backgrounds, all on the *team*. We bring like expertise but like *wisdom as well*, together. This helps solve really "wicked," problems

And climate problems *ARE THE WICKEDIST - THE HEAVIEEEST and A LOT OF OTHER 'ISTS-*, so they NEED *that way* more than ANY OTHER sort to solve it; this might mean talking and listening to farmers facing drought who *know the deal*. Or, it might mean working alongside native folks who have lived *on-the-land*, for time forever to think creatively about things, and they did already solve. I think... I think there might also have an art and science element!

This *Participatory Thingamajig? *it really, has got! It relies on human insight to change up models. The 'Model', which is some deep computer, with data goes in the model BUT NOT PEOPLE! We HAVE to change some human side element or side elements. And maybe if WE join with older ones, THEY join US even too - together, we find our model and solve this. (It helps in, finding different assumptions and maybe better solutions)!! The power lies not just in recycling obsessively - though def get points. We work alongside many folks - on making solutions.

So... yeah! I think taking action means diving in. No more apathy maybe?? Getting involved in community projects like tree  things; demanding and advocating for policy changing from governments? Supporting companies trying to "greenie them"*... I honestly- can not recall if teachers mentioned all that. (Sorry!) We need more community models! Together!
Um. Yeah So we should. Basically save the earth okay!? (sigh... Done!) Finally-!!!

Okay, here's my attempt at a paper. Ugh, climate change. My roommate is snoring already. Procrastinating always bites me.

Climate change. Bad. Extremely bad. Changes everything, right? For the environment. For people. For economies and what have youa very bad situation indeed which calls for action.

And there is plenty we can do! Starting with our, each of and everyone own footprint as in our collective impact as well, so everyone acting together. But figuring out what *actually makes a difference* is the trick, isn't it? Switching to metal straws only matters when production scales up, and sometimes they replace other plastics that degrade better, and all of that, you know? And buying organic can ALSO increase greenhouse and production emissions, because organic farmlands require MORE space, not less. Making consumer choices, real or fake, seem pointless in the face of like giant corporations dumping toxins from smoke stakes, so where do we draw the line? Which makes this hard.

But what *can* we realistically do? Its not all doom and gloom. Oh, wow, its 2:00 AM and that thought made like everything seem, well okay, more hopeful perhaps. But it cant only be up to like individual choices because some researchers are suggesting that those "choices" end up taking responsibility away from real actors! This all points to something about a much deeper responsibility. I recently read in class or, listen I cant recall the specific context a peer reviewed article from *University of Stockholm Scientific Review Board on Existental Ecology*. The author, M. Kaczmarek went into detail regarding exactly like how social activism and awareness creates opportunities for government-led regulation! Their study highlighted a direct correlation between people in power taking aggressive action... Only *after* significant public outcry, but that makes total sense! Like with past political and humanitarian movement, they require massive cultural change before legislative action, but so many big hurdles. What that means for us is like, joining existing campaigns, talking directly with others like our own individual and communal impact. But the point where governments and corporations, are really held on the stand, is with awareness spreading to many like a domino.

All of that sounds greatbut frankly, easy to say... What realistically should just I be capable to even do at all? But like thinking locally. And think communally. But also strategically. Talking to our neighbors feels goodand may have impact, but a focused social message may hold further significance! We just needmore focus. To like be an "impact amplifier." Anyway. Uh oh, I started trailing so its only with the future will further plans can spread like growth spurts in an individual because

Good we can make changes! We got a fight with much love from our group because if not then who will?

topic: Write a 500-word essay about whether standardized testing is fair.
essay_text:
Okay, here's a rough stab at the standardized testing essay. I need coffee

Is standardized testing fair? A simple question! So, what's the answer. Probably not; but that's very complicated. Let's get digging.

Fairness is tricky! Its not like there is one definition, etched in stone somewhere. For students, it encompasses a lot of things, like fair opportunities (of course), fair assessment (obviously), and basically a sense that everything about the test itself makes sense in light that everyone deserves equal possibilities. To say a test has any sort of element of fairness, it'd be ideal if it tested material they've actually learned, be devoid of socio-economic or discriminatory implications, and then it becomes an exercise of legitimate assessment: it makes much much to make it so

But it barely scratches that even though, right? I remember in history class earlier this year that We uhm. We had to read this except from this ancient academic paper... By a professor (probably) somewhere called "A Qualitative Investigation of Psychometric Instrument Performance." No I think, a big article, big points, hard to tell after this long you know when exactly who wrote the thing... Whatever the case, though, I DO, or *at least think* that I remember the the general point of one section in regards to standardized testing regarding access to resources. The article basically did some experiments  you know  control groups and whatever for statistics, on education equality between schools of various localities. Essentially, did the students achieve the same thing when instructed under varying conditions? No! Shock horror! But then there was testing on the thing! The researchers put together that socioeconomic background factors huge into it and impact the standardized tests significantly because access resources  such better public educational services (textbooks etc for example), private tutoring, or even just a safe and quiet space where they could properly study and take good care of sleep  varies wildly between them. Students of poverty might be struggling and not properly nourished while doing and preparing  affecting ability on high-demand exam, like the SATs which can alter life path immensely from education grants that are not accessible anynore; you know. And ultimately this, just this element, puts richer kids a huge advantage than lower SES student which can also discriminate minorities. How! Fair could this posisby truly and deeply every in principle truly be so how how hooo...
There is also culturally loaded content. The test itself assumes some knowledge; which is often tied into white upper-class/middle culture and not other group or students' diverse backgrounds: A reference is made. A metaphor used. It is "easy" only that "cultural background's set of" people which make the standard test taker.

So are these standardized tests fair given the issues related resource bias and cultural context, really truly fair? No.

topic: Write a 500-word essay about whether standardized testing is fair.
essay_text:
Okay, so, the standardized testing debate. Is it really fair? Like, actually fair to every single student? Honestly? Hard to say definitively. Theres so much to consider, okay?

Well, proponents definitely want good results, and use testing as a, like, national yardstick. Standardized tests supposedly level the playing field, providing one way, theoretically to measure everyone against the set metric, despite disparate backgrounds, experiences, or quality of schooling accessible or attended. Doesnt account for much. But they say this way schools too cannot skate by, because even the most under-staffed and under-sourced districts are on equal footing. (or are they?) And, they show trends can be seen - trends about success, and where intervention may become necessary. Good in concept. Sort of vague application in its end. Testing should be fair, and shouldn't it test students the same way that you should expect of them...? 

Of course, the problem immediately introduces it. What happens that student doesnt test well? What happens if even in ideal conditions, with good conditions, something will or could or absolutely must hinder how great he or she actually proves academically? The sheer pressure associated and felt? Different tests. Different styles. Stress. Can they accurately convey potential? Beyond that, we have access problem. Students at well-funded schools can prep much harder with resources, courses, etc. Unequal testing. See? This gives them significant advantage going in even on same academic playing field given simply more exposure. Now, I have a thought about test writing. And also test marking! Even with standardized marking procedures, how will we ever even really confirm if that will bring enough objectivity because the potential for subjective differences is just absolutely glaring? Just is. Some time I was reading one text "Bias in Higher Education Assessment" in my ED class, the one taught by Professor Klein next spring quarter, like, from, I wanna say, like, maybe, Dr Abernathy, and it went into granular details, even something like linguistic bias, and I really zoned when exactly they spoke abou that as the information overload was... a point for sure and it gave my stress and anxiety even when test scores were not in, that that should say itself more about education, with higher regards. What about socio-economic circumstances? Does a gifted kid from a low-income background who has homework or a family dinner still have equal training and testing skills, as would the top student with everything to spare and no troubles in getting the finest pretests to help get it... you knew better...? What I would then give or consider as another thing against a well deserved case, for even or rather or however would describe equality... is it too vague and what about more? Are we simply making too many assumptions upon assumptions and then... just running it. Not a good option. Just making these metrics almost cruel to apply to children and then, to test?

So ultimately? Tough call. But, standardization *should* be at least be reconsidered and carefully re.

essay_text:
Okay, here we go. Standardized testing looms large in our education system. Is it fair? Maybe. Testing important.

The question of fairness in standardized testing is a Gordian knot. On one hand, it seems like a level playing field. Everyone gets the same test, right. Scored the same! But that simplicity masks deep inequalities. Students from privileged backgrounds have access to better resources  private tutoring, test prep courses, quiet study environments. All this. Think about underprivileged kids. Coming from low-income families, they often attend underfunded schools. Makes sense doesnt it? And struggle with basics no time to game practice quizzes. So hard.

And then I remember this article we discussed back like, October? In Dr. Ramirezs education policy class someone, let me think, I genuinely *think* it might have been printed in *The Journal of Remedial and Compensatory Education...*. Or, ugh maybe it was some sort of a white-paper and NOT a formally peer reviewed and cataloged article which would make me SEEM less scholarly AND be embarrassing to mention. Seriously I have a headache. UGH this needs to be done before 9 AM and I havent put up the notes doc. ANYway *THIS SOURCE*  argued (roughly) it was studying educational disparities! Right! Pointed  like, very cleverly -- out. The tests ALREADY reflected bias AGAINST certain groups due to culturally normative frameworks and subtly linguistic expectations and so forth baked carefully the heart testing process from genesis. Stuff beyond preparation, even a question of core assimilation to a dominant (i.e. mainstream affluent white?) cultural understanding. And what do you want it to mean? Isn't that kind of biased? Shouldnt testing be neutral above things that are the result of things? So how do evaluate? Difficult issues. Hard. Super interesting.

Additionally something else that kind of undermines my already shaky confidence in the fairness  I guess. Like if schools teach to the test there's the question on where you focus your efforts because certain questions are going to always be there. Narrow? It isn't real authentic student exploration of intellectual space, thats for certain. It feels more rote. Less deep? A good thing, not like you get testable "core ideas" which are objectively useful across all endeavors like maybe how some of my middle of understanding of math could be very useful... right. I think maybe I needed like tea or some sort of like, pick up now. Really tired! Need. Focus!!! Also is it OK to casually throw out the word rote in a collegiate, professional document about issues of the standardizaiton of secondary curriculum- which I think this qualifies. Is it even a remotely scholarly descriptor...? Does it actually matter anymore as compared putting effort and thought of like a great, perfect verb in now or get stuff in??
In the end, there needs to be much deeper thinking. This assignment proves that I agree  these tests can do so very bad things. It creates even less opportunity for some people, that need some kind of a help too now. It can show you why some problems may have happened; which is hard on you from the side so, really tough and bad just.
But I didn't make a GREAT clear solid conclusion here... eh.

topic: Write a 500-word essay about whether standardized testing is fair.
essay_text:
Alright, let's get this done. Is standardized testing fair? Its a huge question. Likegiant. So Many factors! Hard to say yes or no with confidence but here goes trying to discuss standardized tests.

It touches deeply on core issues of access, equity, and opportunity. Who truly gets a fair shake in the race dictated by these scores anyway? Does a single number have the capability to capture genuine potentials ? What do these tests accurately evaluate anyhow? Questions worth exploring that will be raised and I intend to look at as well. Fair play means level playing field is it even that for students with any sort of disability in schools everywhere or living in poor areas that obviously make school a hard priority with outside issues they deal with constantly? Can it level the field out enough? In the next bit im going to talk about ways that it certainly creates unequal opportunities which will certainly be the focus!

Ah, Okay I remember now. In class  yeah  one of the readings we HAD did something called "The Mismeasure of Maximillian" I think? It was some obscure paper arguing it was inherently baisded to use standardized tests to determine some intelligence metric on Max, its an extreme case of a particularly dim little scamp. What I remember taking from reading about max is pretty good and I thikni understand some of the core tenets which they mention now now. If one person grows up in constant enrichment or advantages versus constant under pressures and a world of constant problems, then there aren't fair playing fields for them- obviously! People are different but for them to truly do well it always helps to come from good opportunities and be able to study well. topic: Write a 500-word essay about whether standardized testing is fair.
essay_text:
Okay, here's that essay. Hope it's good enough. Ugh. Deadline looming!

Standardized testing. Are standardized tests ultimately a bastion of fairness and equal opportunity in evaluating educational success? Not really. So many issues.

Fairness is a slippery concept. Just what *is* 'fair' in testing, anyway?

Okay, deep breath. This is the *biggie*. This is where I unpack all the tangled truths I've been desperately attempting (and arguably, failing already) to recall about standardized testing and its relationship to this nebulous concept of fairness as some ultimate gold standard for evaluating students as well as schools (or districts -- because if *students are tested schools and districts subsequently receive a grade too*... it's interconnected!). Its important to note the tests are not entirely diagnostic; rather it is the ability to respond appropriately to a series of complex, but still limited (and thereby inherently flawed -- as humans make standardized testing by limiting test breadth they can evaluate based on money spent!), multiple choice tests, and let's not forget essay tests too which contain complex guidelines for response and, to make matters *extremely subjective despite efforts to minimize human input through computerized tracking evaluation*, grading by real actual (very much limited by time and often *underpaid*, let not the *testing administration staffing* go under the rubric/heading that evaluates issues of overall testing "Fairness") people, means that these tests only capture ONE data POINT. Consider, do SAT/AP standardized tests measure everything learned over the course of twelve/four respectively years? So. And isn't education -- and understanding -- so much richer and more like, *alive* than bubbled in answers and algorithmically processed content with rigid guideline rubrics and grade standards on what you are *allowed* to present and respond to? A professor -- something like Dr. Aris Vendric or something? Professor something V. -- had this article we sorta glossed over in class, ages ago it feels likesomething, something about how standardized tests unintentionally privilege students. Specifically those studentsoh lord, what *was* it something about socioeconomic backgrounds impacting available resources  tutor access versus a busy mom trying at best but often failing -- to help guide learning and prepare test preperation at the same time due to financial duress resulting in multiple labor-related responsibilities for financial survival in the family household in need... it trails off and the idea ends, but essentially a class bias emerges. Okay, I'll circle back to the source later, if I find it maybe... the general thing about it's that those students, generally, that show great test capability are, already, in a better place socioeconomically; with means to improve on studies (tutors, time, private tutoring, etc...). Also, too - test prep costs a LOT! Test prep costs a damn arm and a leg as well as all your blood to begin with.

Ultimately, fair in standardized test contexts. Impossible. Different advantages so tests unfair! Just tests.

Despite testing *invaluable* to society if its aim for creating more fair environments through educational evaluation, there appears a huge disconnect in achieving what truly encapsulates *FAIR*.
